docs.lead_paragraph: Calling it the biggest disappointment of his career, Gov. Peter Shumlin said Wednesday he was abandoning plans to make Vermont the first state in the country with a universal, publicly funded health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Arkansas became the first Southern state to expand its Medicaid program in a way that many Republicans found acceptable. The state bought private insurance for low-income people instead of adding them to the rolls of the Medicaid system, which GOP lawmakers considered bloated and inefficient.

headline.main: Arkansas' Model Medicaid Experiment in Jeopardy

headline.main: How I Learned to Stop Stressing Over Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Other owners often look at Fred Warmbier in disbelief when he says he’s not interested in spending a lot of time trying to figure out health coverage. It’s a look that says, “Man, you HAVE to manage this closely! What is wrong with you? You’re leaving money on the table.”

docs.lead_paragraph: Senior figures from the Netherlands' two-party ruling coalition held tense talks Wednesday, a day after three Labor Party senators unexpectedly voted down health care legislation and dented confidence in the 2-year-old Cabinet's ability to cooperate on budget-cutting reforms.

docs.lead_paragraph: The tempestuous 113th Congress has limped out of Washington for the last time, capping two years of modest and infrequent legislating that was overshadowed by partisan clashes, gridlock and investigations.

docs.lead_paragraph: In its second year, the much-maligned HealthCare.gov website showed a vastly improved performance.

headline.main: Federal Health Exchange Sees Enrollment Flurry
headline.print_headline: Federal Health Exchange Sees Enrollment Flurry

docs.abstract: Health Sec Sylvia Mathews Burwell reports that nearly 2.5 million people signed up for health insurance plans through the federal marketplace HealthCare.gov during first four weeks of open enrollment, with one million of those enrolling in one week starting Dec 6.
docs.snippet: In its second year, the much-maligned HealthCare.gov website showed a vastly improved performance.
